clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Sugared Chewing Gum on Gastrointestinal Recovery After Major Colorectal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Randomized Controlled Trial of Sugared Chewing Gum on Gastrointestinal Recovery After Major Colorectal Surgery in Patients Managed With Early Enteral Feeding

brief_summary.textblock: The Purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of gum chewing on recovery of gastrointestinal function in patient undergoing major colorectal surgery. The investigators hypothesize that patients who chew gum after major colorectal surgery will have faster recovery of gastrointestinal function.

primary_outcome.measure: Time (in hours) to tolerating a low residue diet
primary_outcome.description: Time measured from end of operation to patient tolerating 50% of a low residue diet without emesis in 24 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Time (in hours) to passage of flatus
secondary_outcome.description: Time from end of operation to first passage of flatus (reported by patient)
Time (hours) from end of operation to first bowel movement
Patient asked to record appetite on a scale from 0 (no appetite) to 10 (appetite as good as can be)
Patient asked to rate pain on VAS scale from 0 (no pain) to 10 (pain as bad as can be)
Patient asked to rate nausea on a scale from 0 (no nausea) to 10 (nausea as bad as can be)

secondary_outcome.measure: Major or Minor Medical and Surgical Complications
Length of postoperative hospitalization in days
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of postoperative hospitalization (expected average of 5 days)

arm_group.description: Patient asked to chew sugared chewing gum postoperative day 1 to 7, 3 times a day, 45 minutes at a time
No gum given, routine postoperative care provided

intervention.description: One stick of gum, 3 times daily from Postoperative day 1 to 7

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Able to freely give written informed consent to participate in the study and have signed the Informed Consent Form
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Class I-III (Appendix III);
- Due to undergo small and/or large partial bowel resection via laparotomy or laparoscopy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mentally incompetent or unable or unwilling to provide informed consent or comply with study procedures
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Class IV or V;
- History of abdominal carcinomatosis
- History of radiation enteritis
- Children < 18 or adults > 85 years of age
